{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3559607,"name":"JedG","username":"JedG","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/jedg/{size}/244692_2.png","created_at":"2025-03-17T19:20:42.231Z","cooked":"

Students have been trying out different climbing mechanisms to no avail unfortunately.

Figured I’d ask the community if anyone has any ideas that might work with our robot.

Biggest problem is the elevator is placed fairly far back and even with the ramp actuated up we’re still having issues with the anchor touching the robot or not being able to reel in the cage enough at all to lift up.

I’m not the most mechanically inclined (programming mentor who likes to throw out a bunch of mechanism ideas and see what sticks) but personally I think a “hugging” mechanism similar to 3847/1323/4414 would work.

Possibly with a raised bar or 10” bumpers to create a pivot point in order for the cage to be less inside our robot. I can see slipping issues with that idea though. Seems you need a hook at the bottom like 3847 does.

Any ideas would be appreciated

IMG_19554284×5712 5.05 MB

IMG_19504284×5712 6.58 MB

This architecture is almost Identical to our (3255) robot. This exact problem was our biggest struggle this year to figure out. We ended up having a “foot” that deploys out with a series of wheels on it that allows the cage to kind of pivot around the bumpers and keeps the cage far enough outisde the robot to keep the anchor away from the elevator. The latch mechanism is less than optimal and we have talked about updating it to make it simpler to line up and latch, but it works for now.

Are you considering doing a shallow climb or a deep climb? The answer varies significantly based on which. I think a shallow climb would be significantly easier here, where you could place two hooks on the sides of the elevator and push down on the cage, rapid react style. A deep climb is way harder, and idk the solution to that.

Just a deep climb as we figured a shallow climb isn’t worth the effort for the amount of points/second it would take.

The students have been cooking with some ideas though!

Think we may have it solved
